owl:Class.rdfs:comment: "Assessment, Test, Verification and Evaluation – Test is the dynamic activity aiming at to run a program or model in a controlled manner using some specific entries and verify whether the behavior is according to specifications in order to identify defects or ensure its reliability. There are various kinds of tests, e.g., Functional, Penetration, Fuzzing, Fault or Defect Injection, Exploratory, etc. Verification is the activity aiming at verifies whether a requirement is present, without a test of the functionality. There are various kinds of verification, e.g., Compliance (with rules or regulations), Formal Methods, Vulnerability Analysis, Reverse engineering, Social engineering, Business Rules, etc. The term Assessment is more generic and includes testing and verifying activities. Evaluation is considered synonymous of Assessment in this context."

"Assessment Criteria – Assessment criteria are rules that define how we will execute the assessment. Assessment criteria define requirements to be satisfied, namely: how to select assessment data; how to verify the quality of assessment activity; and how to define the sufficiency of requirements for the end of assessment activities. "

"Assessment Dimension – Scope of assessment, i.e., define under which views the system must be evaluated. Assessment Dimensions are: Business Logic; System Architecture; Process; System in Runtime (Black Box); Source Code (White Box); and Operating Environment. Assessment Dimension 1. Business Logic – This dimension aims to evaluate the system requirements, searching for vulnerable points or absences in the system specification that could be legitimately exploited. Business logic faults cannot be detected in code review. Assessment Dimension 2. System Architecture – This dimension aims to evaluate the system design, searching for vulnerable points or absences that could cause the system to not operate properly (e.g.: vulnerable protocols, unsecure interoperability, mobility problems, etc. Assessment Dimension 3. Process – This dimension aims to evaluate processes and procedures of system, searching for vulnerable points or absences that could interfere with correct operation of the system. Thus, this dimension is intended to assess the overall context, before and after the system, trying to identify points of process where the system is inserted but that are beyond the scope of software requirements. E.g.: Access authorization and attribution of profiles, schedules of use and operation, criteria for physical access to resources or facilities, etc. Assessment Dimension 4. System in Runtime (Black Box) – This dimension aims to evaluate the system execution, searching for vulnerabilities or absences that could be exploited in the case of incorrect configuration or incorrect use, intentionally or not. Assessment Dimension 5. Source Code (White Box) – This dimension aims to evaluate the system source code, searching for vulnerabilities or absences that could be exploited. E.g.: vulnerable libraries, incorrect algorithms, unsecure functions or fragile parameters. Assessment Dimension 6. Operating Environment – This dimension aims to evaluate the system's operating environment, searching for vulnerabilities or absences that could be exploited. Operating environments are: Operating Systems, Support Systems and Network Infrastructure where the system will operate. For example: unsecure versions, protocols or configurations in operating systems or communications networks that will support the system under evaluation. "

"Assessment Item – Assessment Items are assessment requirements, such as test cases, verification items, standard controls, aiming at to find defects or faults in SUT (System Under Test). Assessment Items has an expected result and a procedure (script) to execute them. "
Certification relates to "certify", "formal concession", and submission to regulation". Product: Certificate.
"Defect, Fault – It is a deficiency or lack in a step, process or in definition of data. Resident in the program, when executed, a defect may cause an error."
"Error – It is an inconsistent or unexpected condition of the program. It is an incorrect value or incorrect sequence in a given status of the program. It is caused by the execution of a defect. "

"Assessment, Test, Verification and Evaluation – Test is the dynamic activity aiming at to run a program or model in a controlled manner using some specific entries and verify whether the behavior is according to specifications in order to identify defects or ensure its reliability. There are various kinds of tests, e.g., Functional, Penetration, Fuzzing, Fault or Defect Injection, Exploratory, etc. Verification is the activity aiming at verifies whether a requirement is present, without a test of the functionality. There are various kinds of verification, e.g., Compliance (with rules or regulations), Formal Methods, Vulnerability Analysis, Reverse engineering, Social engineering, Business Rules, etc. The term Assessment is more generic and includes testing and verifying activities. Evaluation is considered synonymous of Assessment in this context."
"Failure – It results from error propagation. A failure is noticed when the produced result is different from the expected result. "
"Defect, Fault – It is a deficiency or lack in a step, process or in definition of data. Resident in the program, when executed, a defect may cause an error."
Homologation relates to "ratify", "affirm", "confirm", "validate", "verify", "examine", "check" and "approve". Product: Report.

"Knowledge Source – Knowledge Sources are references or standards used in the assessment process that provide a set of assessment items. For example: Standards, Patterns, Methods, Checklists, Previous Cases, etc."

"Mistake – It is human action that can produce a defect. Programmers (development phase), Engineers (project phase) or Operators (deployment phase) make mistakes for various reasons (forgetfulness, lack of knowledge, etc.)."

"Result Analysis of Assessment – The process of result analysis of assessment can be divided in Homologation and Certification. Homologation relates to “ratify”, “affirm”, “confirm”, and “approve”. The products of the homologation are: Reports of Assessment, Analysis, and Testing. Generally, a homologation has the following characteristics: usually not disclosed; it is subject to appeal or recourse; it is tied to a specific version of system or software. Certification relates to “certify”, “formal concession”, and “submission to regulation”. The products of the certification are: compliance certificate with a standard; and formal statement by means of certificate or equivalent document. Generally, the certification has the following characteristics: usually disclosed; low likelihood of appeal or recourse; it is tied to a specific version of system or software, or also a period of time; may involve gaining prerogatives and rights. "

"Assessment, Test, Verification and Evaluation – Test is the dynamic activity aiming at to run a program or model in a controlled manner using some specific entries and verify whether the behavior is according to specifications in order to identify defects or ensure its reliability. There are various kinds of tests, e.g., Functional, Penetration, Fuzzing, Fault or Defect Injection, Exploratory, etc. Verification is the activity aiming at verifies whether a requirement is present, without a test of the functionality. There are various kinds of verification, e.g., Compliance (with rules or regulations), Formal Methods, Vulnerability Analysis, Reverse engineering, Social engineering, Business Rules, etc. The term Assessment is more generic and includes testing and verifying activities. Evaluation is considered synonymous of Assessment in this context."

"Assessment, Test, Verification and Evaluation – Test is the dynamic activity aiming at to run a program or model in a controlled manner using some specific entries and verify whether the behavior is according to specifications in order to identify defects or ensure its reliability. There are various kinds of tests, e.g., Functional, Penetration, Fuzzing, Fault or Defect Injection, Exploratory, etc. Verification is the activity aiming at verifies whether a requirement is present, without a test of the functionality. There are various kinds of verification, e.g., Compliance (with rules or regulations), Formal Methods, Vulnerability Analysis, Reverse engineering, Social engineering, Business Rules, etc. The term Assessment is more generic and includes testing and verifying activities. Evaluation is considered synonymous of Assessment in this context."

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: "Authenticity – System allows prove the veracity of a particular act or document. This property is regarding whether information or documents are true (authentic) or false."
rdf:Description.isIdentifiedBy: authentic; originality; origin; veracity; truth; true; false;

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: "Traceability – System records information about critical actions, in order to enable reassembly of the history of actions, when it is necessary."
rdf:Description.isIdentifiedBy: record; report; memory; raw data; accountability; log; evidence; history; origin; action;

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: "Privacy – System does not disclose indiscriminately, or without specific permission, information about personal intimacy (personal information). This intimacy has several levels of perception."
rdf:Description.isIdentifiedBy: confidential; classified; secrecy; private; personal; individual; particular; specific; single; proper; own;

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: "Non-repudiation – System records corroborative evidences of important acts, so as not to allow users or other systems refuse the authorship of performed actions."
rdf:Description.isIdentifiedBy: evidence; proof; record; act; action; user; author; authorship; perform; refuse; reject; discard; refuse; decline; deny; repudiate; responsibility, commitment; duty; incumbency;

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: "Auditability – System has capability to generate and provide evidences that security requirements have been achieved."
rdf:Description.isIdentifiedBy: audit; evidence; compliance; requirement; certification; homologation;

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: "Resilience – System is able to continue operating even though in adverse conditions, such as operating environment problems, or failures caused by cyber attacks."
rdf:Description.isIdentifiedBy: resist; withstand; endure; ensure; preserve; keep; bear; tolerate; oppose; detain; stop; block; defend; protect; survival; adverse; attack; operation; failures; resilient; strong; hard; robust; durable;

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: "Non-retroactivity – The system does not allow perform actions or generate documents retroactively in time."
rdf:Description.isIdentifiedBy: retroactive; date; period; term; action; time; expiration; backward

rdf:Description.distanceFromAvailability: "Availability – Information or system is accessible and usable when demanded."
rdf:Description.isIdentifiedBy: available; usable; run; operating; work; perform; stress;

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: "Legality – System and process are in accordance with applicable law or regulation."
rdf:Description.isIdentifiedBy: law; standard; regulation; governance; rule; ordinance; statute; legal; licit; valid; legitimate; compliance; submission; observance;

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: "Integrity – Information or system have not been modified or destroyed in an unauthorized or accidental way. This property is regarding whether the information is correct or whether the system provides correct data."
rdf:Description.isIdentifiedBy: create; modify; edit; delete; destroy; correct; data; backup;

process; documentation; relation; service; date; hour; time; store; user; responsability; profile; policy; management; organization; measure; commitment; assignment; responsability; responsabilities; role; protection; asset; NDA; Non-Disclosure Agreement; agreement; disclosure; legal; enforce; procedure; incident; law; enforcement; review; change; implementation;
operating system; network; database; SGBD; support; monitoring; infraestructure; communication; configuration;

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: "Confidentiality – Information is accessible and usable only for authorized users or systems. Usually, profiles, levels or degrees of secrecy are defined."
rdf:Description.isIdentifiedBy: secrecy; confidential; reserved; secret; top-secret; permission; allow; clearance; protect; access; authorize; profile; role; level;
